turn.text: Yes, he supervises district attorneys under the California constitution and he can prosecute them and if there is a conflict he can come in and he is to enforce the law against them as well and the grand jury is to enforce the law against him, but what the prosecutor does in the courtroom, what he does and indicts his subject to the constant review with the court do to the Sixth Amendment.
He has an adversary and that is I think the great distinction.
Well, thank you very much.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: You said that -- you started to say earlier that the quasi-judicial has two meanings.
You never were able to elaborate or finish that because I think you were interrupted?

turn.speaker: john_p_farrell
turn.label: Mr. John P. Farrell
turn.text: Yes, what I was --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Can you tell us what your concept was at the first meeting, a first meeting somebody like a magistrate or somebody, at least at that time performs what seem to be judicial functions and duties?

turn.speaker: john_p_farrell
turn.label: Mr. John P. Farrell
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: That is the first one.

turn.speaker: john_p_farrell
turn.label: Mr. John P. Farrell
turn.text: The first emphasis is on the discretion which is similar to a judge and the second meaning is when the person closely identified and subject to the control of the judge and quasi-judicial immunity, for instance, has been given to marshals and sheriffs and clerks carrying out the orders of the court where there is no great discretion but it is identified with the judicial process.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Supporting personnel in the courtroom?

turn.speaker: john_p_farrell
turn.label: Mr. John P. Farrell
turn.text: Supporting personnel and people are acting under their control and I think I was trying to say what District Attorney is both exercising the discretion which is similar to a judge and he is there when he is arguing a case, when he is presenting evidence to the court is subject to the constant control of the court, and so he falls under both ends of quasi-judicial definition.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Very well.
Mr. Solicitor General.

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice and may it please the Court.
United States is interested in this case because the outcome of it will quite likely affect the scope of the immunity for Federal prosecutors and may in some sense control it.
I think the main points have been well canvassed by counsel.

The problem of harassment that may occur to a prosecutor I think is illustrated in some ways by this case because we have seven judges in the California Supreme Court who thought the conduct here did not deny the petitioner his constitutional rights and we have two Federal Courts who thought it did and I think it is fair to say that when judges differ that substantially about the nature of this conduct and what it did to petitioner’s rights.
It is fair to say that nobody can be confident of the outcome of the jury case.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: That goes to the merits, however, does it not, Mr. Solicitor General?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: Well, I was not going to the merits in the sense Mr. Chief Justice that I meant to imply that either court was right or wrong.
I have been merely illustrating the degree of uncertainty that exists in all of these kinds of cases.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: That does not go to the main issue of the risk of harassment of prosecutors in the diversion of their time from their basic function?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: I meant to go that point Mr. Chief Justice because I think --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Mr. Solicitor General, there has always been attention between state courts, I can say from personal experience in federal habeas corpus?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: I am sure there is.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: There is nothing new about that.

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: No, no.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: I suggest on the issue that we are dealing with today.
I do not see that an attention helps us as well?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: Well, in that case I will not pursue the point.
I was trying to put it somewhat differently, but it is not what my main point, in any event I will pass it.
What I would like to discuss is the conceptual framework of the absolute immunity and the qualified immunity and why I think this particular process requires an absolute immunity.
Petitioner’s counsel objected to this being called a quasi-judicial immunity because the prosecutor is an executive branch officer, but I think there is no anomaly there.
The categorization does not come from the equation of which branch of government you are employed by.
It comes from the process in which you are engaged, the nature of the process in which one is engaged.

This happens to be executive branch employee who is intimately involved in a judicial process and it is the appropriate immunity for -- is shaped by the needs of the process and I think that is why this is called the quasi-judicial immunity and that is why that absolute immunity which adheres to judges has properly been held to adhere to prosecutors in Yaselli against Goff.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: At the actual trial of the case, I still have not got it clear in my mind the difference between the prosecutor and defense counsel as to who is a quasi-judicial officer.
This is during the trial in asking questions?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: I do not see Mr. Justice Marshall that should a defense counsel suborn in perjury that he would be liable to anyone in a damage action.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, I mean is he a quasi-judicial officer?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: I assume he is.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: What?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: I assume he is.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: So there is no difference.
He also is a quasi judicial officer?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: I think the people engaged in this process are –- Pardon me.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: I believe so.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Is the privately retained defense counsel an agent of the state for purposes of 1983?.

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: Oh! No, no.
The question was in general.

Can the defense counsel be regarded as performing a quasi-judicial function and within the terminology which we are using now, I think the answer is yes, now of course there would be not state action.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: That is right.

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: Under the 1983.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Unless he was a public defender, publicly paid?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: Something of that sort.
We are saying that this nature of the process defines the immunity of the judge and of the prosecutor and indeed that the prosecutor’s immunity is symmetrical with the judge’s immunity.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Even if we say that the public defender is paid by the public, are you sure that that makes that state action in light of your definition that it is not the category or class in which we put in the function that he performs?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: I am not sure it is state action Mr. Chief Justice.
I had not addressed the question of the state action of a public defender.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Then you do not need to worry about the defense counsel here in this case?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: No, we do not have to worry about them.

It is merely a question whether this idea of quasi-judicial aspect covered defense counsel as well, I think as a general concept it does, but I think that is nothing do with this case and the point I wish to make here is that I think the immunity which a prosecutor has is symmetrical with that which the judge has because they are both essential to the judicial process.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: We will resume there at 1 o’clock Mr. Solicitor General.
[Lunch Break]

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Mr. Solicitor General, you may continue.

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice and may it please the Court.

I ended on the note that the immunity was defined by the process and for that reason that the prosecutor’s immunity was appropriate of the same size as the judge’s immunity and that would mean that a case parallel to this would be the case of a judge who was reversed for misconduct of the trial during which he had denied a litigant his constitutional rights.
I take it that Pierson against Ray and Yaselli against Goff -- Pierson against Ray means that that judgment nevertheless would have absolute immunity.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: The analog would be a judge who had done so deliberately and intentionally and knowingly?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: Yes, Mr. Justice Stewart that is correct.
The judge would --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Not just because of ignorance?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: No, with malice.

We also have indicted judges from time to time and so that would be analog to this case and I think if that judge would have an absolute immunity as indeed I think he would from a damage suit I think so a prosecutor should, then I think the perception or the difference is between the governor’s decision making range and what is at stake here is what the counsel difference between this case and Pierson against Ray and the case of Scheuer against Rhodes and the greatest difference which I think --

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Mr. Solicitor General I gather that the question I put to Mr. (Inaudible) a judge himself a decision would have the absolute immunity, would he not?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: From the damage suit I believe yes so.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Yes, I mean from the damage suit.
Do you agree with him that perhaps one prosecutor who bribes the witness, would not?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: No, I do not think I would be willing to say that --

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: That carries the absolute immunity even to that prosecutor?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: A great deal of what prosecutor does, it is done outside of the courtroom and I do not really see that in the performance of his prosecutorial function that makes that much difference whether he happens to be standing on the hall or in his office or in the courtroom.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Of course, Mr. Solicitor General the decision the Court affirmed in Goff v. Yaselli would affirm the judgment of the Court of Appeals and saw no difference between judges and other executive officers?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: Well, there may be.
There has been a doctrine of absolute immunity for other executive officers.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Which the Court of Appeals in Yaselli has found?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: Yes.

But I think that Scheuer indicates and Wood against Strickland indicates some difference and I am suggesting for executive officers at least in the state context and I am suggesting that difference between that case in Pierson against Ray or Yaselli against Goff is justified by the difference in the process and one of those differences as is, as we said in the Scheuer opinion, I am quoting from Mr. Chief Justice Hughes that where they not judicial review in the damage suit, there would be no way to test the governor’s performance in a courtroom and defy another state governor would be the constitution and not the constitution by the Supreme Law.
That is not true here.

A prosecutor’s behavior is testable in the courtroom before the jury, it is testable on appeal, it is testable on collateral attack and indeed it is testable ultimately if one gets to that stage upon a petition for commutation of sentence or pardon.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Are you familiar with the Ninth Circuit’s holding in Ronan against Robichaud?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: I do not believe I am Mr. Justice Rehnquist.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, that was a case where the prosecutor had apparently collaborator, who was alleged he collaborated kind of third degree methods in interrogating a witness, would you extend absolute immunity that far?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: There are cases that I think we need not reach for purposes of this case in which a prosecutor does what is regarded as essentially a police function, as in directing a raid or interrogating a witness and it is possible to draw that line.
I would be hesitant to draw it very easily because the connection between what he is going to do in the courtroom and what he does outside the courtroom is so close.
There may be cases in which that line can be drawn.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: That is so called an investigative function, is it not?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: That is true.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: And at least three circuits have thought there was a distinction?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: And there may be.
I do not think we need to address that distinction for the purposes of today’s case.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And do they, do those decisions say that he then has the immunity of a policeman or he has no immunity at all?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: I think it becomes a qualified immunity I believe.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: The immunity of a policeman if he is acting like a policeman?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: Yes, Mr. Justice Stewart.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: That is what the cases say?
I believe so.

But the one thing I want to stress here is that in this case, unlike the case of a governor or school official, the prosecutor’s action is subject to repeated review and repeated collateral attack which would not be true if the governor in Scheuer against Rhodes, will not be true if the school officials in Wood against Strickland were not for their not having absolute immunity.
It has been mentioned that besides the other safeguards for the defendant, there are sanctions available against a prosecutor which are not available against the governor such as --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: What happens to executive officer who directs a prosecutor to prosecute?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: Well, it is the executive.
I mean, a governor who directs an executive officer?

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: To prosecute that would be somewhat difficult case because at that point the governor I take it is exercising his function to make sure the laws are executed in the sense.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: He is acting like the prosecutor?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: He is acting like a prosecutor.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Rather than the prosecutor is acting like a governor?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: That I think is true, but we are talking about a governor calling out the National Guard.
We are talking about the situation in which there is no way to get judicial review of that action, if there is not a 1983 suit available.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Is it not true that in most of the states, neither the Governor of the State nor the Attorney General has any final control over the actions of a prosecutor?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: That is I believe true (Voice Overlap)

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: MThe Governor can remove or suspend the prosecutor temporarily for clause, but overwhelmingly the prosecutor elected in a particular jurisdiction is autonomous.
Is that not so?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: I think that is quite true Mr. Chief Justice.
It may be that my answer to Mr. Justice White was somewhat tempered by my knowledge that the Attorney General can direct prosecution.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: In the federal --

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: In the federal system and our interest is of course in the federal system.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And even if they can, it often happens in the states they nevertheless listen?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: That may, will be.
I am not that familiar with state.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: It is a matter of technicality?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: But I think also it is true that judicial process that we are trying to protect with this kind of immunity is a more vulnerable process.

It is quite true that prosecutors have to bring many cases and they have antipathy from many defendants and there are categories of defendants who if they were able to sue would do their best to bring the process to a halt or at least the damage of the process by bringing actions.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Solicitor General, I know that your brief has given us a rather comprehensive review of all the Federal Court decisions addressed in this question, but you made no reference to lower or any state court decisions, is there any reason for that?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: No, we did not Justice Brennan because we think at least as to the federal prosecutor’s immunity it is governed by federal law.
Now, perhaps I do not know if these gentlemen wish to file the brief, I thought you were asking about this morning.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, it is a good deal of state law?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: Well, shall I ask this gentlemen if they --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: The state decisions would be construing 1983.
The only reason we have this case is because it involves a federal question of the construction of a federal statute?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: I think Mr. Justice Brennan is interested more than 1983.
He is interested in --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: I am familiar with it.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, any state can do whatever he wants about this it is a matter of its own State Tort Law?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: That is true, I think --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Pierson against Ray and those cases called on the historic privilege under common law?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: That is true.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: It is true in 1983?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: But we have --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Yes, but so the question is that -- that may be common law may be of some relevance in the various states?

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Do not let me hold?

turn.speaker: robert_h_bork
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Bork
turn.text: Alright I think.
(Voice Overlap) It should also be noted that the prosecutor has to establish his case beyond a reasonable doubt to unanimous jury.

Should he be reversed on appeal for having done something or be attacked collaterally, he will be sued under a standard by which a majority of the jury may hold him liable on the preponderance of the evidence.
I think that is bound to have a deterred effect as the prosecutor decides whether or not to go forward with the case.

And finally, I think it may be worth noting that I think it is true that some courts would be a little loathe in a close case to decide if the defendant had been denied his constitutional rights by a prosecutor if that court knew that by doing so he was exposing the prosecutor to a lawsuit for damages.
It is not all clear that removing the absolute immunity would help the defendants.
It might in fact hurt some defendants on their habeas corpus proceedings.
In any event for these reasons we think the absolute immunity which a court has, a judge has, and a juror has properly belongs to a prosecutor as well.
There are other sanctions, other safeguards in the judicial process not available elsewhere and for that reason we thank the judgment of the Court of Appeals should be affirmed.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Thank you Mr. Solicitor General.
Thank you gentlemen.
The case is submitted.
